creator: greening@bigtribe.com
text:
When there is a hyphen in a tag definition, viz:

   <tag name="ejb.resource-ref" description="xdoclet" enabled="false"/>

used to suppress warnings in <javadoc>, the <javadoc> tag apparently records
this as the tag "ejb.resource" not "ejb.resource-ref".  You get these two warnings:

  [javadoc] C:\greening\AgeoSessionEJB.java:63: warning - @ejb.resource-ref is
an unknown tag.

and

  [javadoc] Note: Custom tags that were not seen:  @ejb.resource

Seems like a bug in some pattern somewhere.  Very annoying!

(A related request is to be able to suppress errors using patterns, such as "ejb.*")

It is more that the javadoc tool suppresses the tag.
The -debug flags shows that an attempt is made tell javadoc:

'-tag'
'a.a-b:Xt:x'

The "-" is actually a separator.
The doc for javadoc give an example of how to use ":" in a tag,
but not a "-" in a tag.
The javadoc task does not handle a ":" in a tag as well... so changing
the title.

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/tooldocs/solaris/javadoc.html#colon
creator: peter.reilly@corvil.com
stevel@apache.org
text:
This could all be the behaviour of javadoc itself. Dan, can you replicate the
problem on the command line of javadoc -if that is the case then we are probably
not in a position to do anything about it.

creator: jakarta@ehatchersolutions.com
text:
XDoclet switched to using the dot as a separator rather than the colon for this very reason.  The 
two are interchangeable with XDoclet 1.2 - but I recommend using a dot.

I did use a dot, not a colon.  For reasons this is happening, see this document:

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/tooldocs/windows/javadoc.html#tag

The problem does occur on the command line argument, so it's either a bug in
Javadoc, or a bug in the names used by Xdoclet.  Annoying.
